{{about||other buildings called Times Square Building|Times Square Building (disambiguation)|other New York Times Buildings|New York Times Building (disambiguation)}} {{use mdy dates|date=August 2012}} {{use American English|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox building |name = 229 West 43rd Street |image = Old NY Times Building 01.jpg |image_size = 250px |caption = Upper floors of building (December 2009) |alt = |former_names = New York Times Annex
The New York Times Building |location = 229 West 43rd Street
[[Manhattan]], New York City |coordinates = {{coord|40.757557|-73.987783|region:US-NY_dim:5km|format=dms|display=inline,title}} |architectural_style= [[Gothic Revival architecture|Neo-Gothic]]
[[French Renaissance architecture|French Renaissance]] (addition) |status = |start_date = 1912 |completion_date = 1913 |opening = |building_type = [[Office building]] |antenna_spire = |renovation_date = 1922 (addition)
1931–32 (addition) |roof = {{convert|267|ft|m|abbr=on}} |top_floor = |floor_count = 18 |elevator_count = |cost = |floor_area = {{convert|767000|sqft|m2}}Rubinstein, Dana (September 23, 2008). [http://www.observer.com/2008/real-estate/sign-times-landlord-leviev-adding-32-foot-sign-229-west-43rd "Sign for ''The Times'': Landlord Leviev Adding 32-Foot Sign to 229 West 43rd"]. ''[[New York Observer]]''. Retrieved August 6, 2012. |architect = [[Buchman & Fox|Mortimer J. Fox]] (original)
[[Ludlow and Peabody]] (1922 addition)
[[Albert Kahn (architect)|Albert Kahn]] (1932 addition) |structural_engineer= |main_contractor = |developer = [[The New York Times Company]] |owner = Columbia Property Trust |management = Columbia Property Trust | embedded = {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = NYC | designation1_date = 24 April 2001 | designation1_number = [http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/lp/2091.pdf LP-2091] }} |references = {{cite web|url=https://www.emporis.com/buildings/115775/new-york-times-building-new-york-city-ny-usa|title=New York Times Building|website=[[Emporis]]|accessdate=27 March 2017}} }} '''229 West 43rd Street''', formerly known as '''The New York Times Building''',{{cite book|last=Lankevich|first=George J.|title=Postcards from Times Square|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fSv3JxmjLo4C&pg=PA1892&dq=One+Times+Square&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjBlufboK7QAhXDWiwKHQWGCS8Q6AEIRTAF#v=onepage&q=One%20Times%20Square&f=false|publisher=Square One Publishers, Inc.|date=2001|page=20|isbn=9780757001000}} is an 18-story ({{convert|267|ft|m|abbr=on|disp=x|;}}) [[office building]], located at 229 West 43rd Street between [[Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)|Seventh]] and [[Eighth Avenue (Manhattan)|Eighth Avenue]] near [[Times Square]] in [[Manhattan]], a [[borough (New York City)|borough]] of [[New York City]]. It was the headquarters of ''[[The New York Times]]'' newspaper from 1913 through 2007.{{cite web|title=History of Times Square|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/8664743/History-of-Times-Square.html|date=27 July 2011|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group|The Telegraph]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310182554/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/8664743/History-of-Times-Square.html|archivedate=10 March 2016}}{{cite press release|title=The New York Times Company Enters The 21st Century With A New Technologically Advanced And Environmentally Sensitive Headquarter|url=http://www.newyorktimesbuilding.com/pdf/FactSheet2007.pdf|publisher=[[The New York Times]] Company|date=16 November 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227024735/http://www.newyorktimesbuilding.com/pdf/FactSheet2007.pdf|archivedate=27 February 2008}} ==History== The building was built in three stages between 1912 and 1937. It was originally designed by Mortimer J. Fox, of the firm [[Buchman & Fox]], and called the '''New York Times Annex''' because it was designed to supplement the [[One Times Square]] Times Tower, built in 1905 at Broadway and 42nd Street (which gives Times Square its name). In 1922, the Ludlow & Peabody firm designed a {{convert|100|ft|adj=on}} extension on the west side as well as a five-story setback attic level in the style of the [[French Renaissance]], including the [[Mansard roof]]s.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} From 1930 to 1932, architect [[Albert Kahn (architect)|Albert Kahn]] designed a further expansion to the west including a second lobby and roof-top studio. Further expansions included a 12-story New York Times North building adjoining it to the north on 44th Street. The New York Times Company sold the building in 2004 to [[Tishman Speyer|Tishman Speyer Properties]] for $175 million. Tishman sold it to [[Africa Israel Investments]] in 2007 for $525 million.Koblin, John (April 30, 2007). [http://observer.com/2007/04/times-building-sells-again-for-525-m/ "Times Building Sells (Again!) For $525 M."]. ''[[New York Observer]]''. Retrieved August 6, 2012. {{As of|September 2008}}, Africa Israel was in the midst of a $175 million renovation including adding a new sign on the top and replacing a digital clock in place since 1962 with an analog version.Dunlap, David W. (September 23, 2008). [http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/09/23/signs-of-change-in-lights-for-times-square/?scp=5&sq=one%20times%20square%20owner&st=cse "Signs of Change, in Lights, for Times Square"]. ''City Room'' (blog of ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved August 6, 2012. Africa Israel officially calls it "The Times Square Building". In 2015, [[Jared Kushner]] purchased $295 million worth of space in the former New York Times Building on 43rd Street near from Lev Avnerovich Leviev's firms Africa Israel Investments and Five Mile Capital.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/19/business/big-german-bank-key-to-trumps-finances-faces-new-scrutiny.html|title=Big German Bank, Key to Trump’s Finances, Faces New Scrutiny|date=July 19, 2017|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|last1=Protess|first1=Ben|last2=Silver-Greenberg|first2=Jessica|last3=Drucker|first3=Jesse|access-date=November 12, 2018}} Later, in October 2016, Kushner used this space as a basis for a $285 million loan from [[Deutsche Bank]].{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/kushner-firms-285-million-deutsche-bank-loan-came-just-before-election-day/2017/06/25/984f3acc-4f88-11e7-b064-828ba60fbb98_story.html?utm_term=.abc4038ac7a4|title=Kushner firm’s $285 million Deutsche Bank loan came just before Election Day|date=June 25, 2017|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|last=Kranish|first=Michael|access-date=November 12, 2018}} These deals attracted [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|special counsel]] [[Robert Mueller]]'s attention as [[Links between Trump associates and Russian officials|possible ties]] between Trump family real estate deals and Russian money interests while he is investigating alleged [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jul/24/jared-kushner-new-york-russia-money-laundering|title=Jared Kushner sealed real estate deal with oligarch's firm cited in money-laundering case|date=July 24, 2017|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|last1=Dent|first1=Wendy|last2=Pilkington|first2=Ed|last3=Walker|first3=Shaun|access-date=November 12, 2018}} ==Occupants== {{update section|date=August 2015}} From 2009-2016, the basement housed [[Discovery Times Square Exposition|Discovery TSX]].{{registration required|date=August 2012}} [[Edward Rothstein|Rothstein, Edward]] (June 25, 2009). [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/26/arts/design/26discovery.html?ref=design "Relics From the Deep and the Dawn of Man"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved June 26, 2009.. [[National Geographic Encounter]]: Ocean Odyssey, operated by [[Times Square Attractions Live]] opened in that space in 2017.{{cite news |last1=Dunlap |first1=David W. |title=An Ocean Beckons Where Newspapers Once Streamed |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/04/insider/an-ocean-beckons-where-newspapers-once-streamed.html |accessdate=4 July 2018 |work=New York Times |date=2017-05-04}} Since April 2013, the 5th floor has housed [[MongoDB Inc.]] (formerly [[10gen]]), a database company.{{cite web|title=10gen Moves to Former New York Times Building|url=http://www.10gen.com/press/10gen-moves-former-new-york-times-building|accessdate=29 April 2013}} Some of the 6th and 7th floors is [[Snapchat]], as well the entire 15th and 16th (top) floors and the 16th floor 673 sq ft tower. [[Yahoo!]] is on the 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th and 14th floors. In December 2017, Complex Networks subleased 80,000 square feet of space from Yahoo.{{cite web|url=https://therealdeal.com/2017/12/14/complex-networks-inks-sublease-with-yahoo-at-229-west-43rd-st/|title=Complex Networks inks sublease with Yahoo at 229 West 43rd St.|author=|date=December 14, 2017|website=therealdeal.com|accessdate=February 4, 2018}} PubMatic{{cite web|url=http://pubmatic.com|title=Automation Solutions for Digital Advertising - PubMatic|author=|date=|website=PubMatic|accessdate=February 4, 2018}} and the Worth Global Style Network are on the 7th floor. AlphaSights is on the 4th floor.{{cite web|url=http://www.alphasights.com/|title=Home - AlphaSights|author=|date=|website=www.alphasights.com|accessdate=February 4, 2018}} As of June, 2016, Engine Group is on the 8th floor, including ORC International, Deep Focus and Moment Studio.{{cite web|url=http://www.enginegroup.com/|title=Home Page – Engine Group}} [[Snap Inc.]] currently rents 25% of the building.{{Cite web|url=http://columbia.reit/properties/229-west-43rd-street|title=229 West 43rd Street|last=|first=|date=|website=Columbia Property Trust|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-02-28}} The bottom two floors are owned by [[Kushner Companies]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2017/02/new-york-times-digital-journalism/|title=How The New York Times Is Clawing Its Way into the Future|last=Snyder|first=Gabriel|work=WIRED|access-date=2017-03-18|language=en-US}} [[Bowlmor Lanes]] opened some lanes in the building.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/19/nyregion/19bowlmor.html|title=Bowlmor Lanes in Former Newsroom of The New York Times|last=Barry|first=Dan|date=2010-11-18|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-03-18|issn=0362-4331}} ==See also== {{portal|Architecture|Journalism|New York City}} * [[1913 in architecture]] * [[List of buildings, sites, and monuments in New York City]] * [[List of New York City Designated Landmarks in Manhattan from 14th to 59th Streets]] * [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Manhattan from 14th to 59th Streets]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{NY Times}} [[Category:Newspaper headquarters in the United States]] [[Category:Newspaper buildings]] [[Category:1913 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Commercial buildings completed in 1913]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Times Square buildings]] [[Category:The New York Times]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]] [[Category:Landmarks in Manhattan]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Multiple issues| {{notability|1=Biographies|date=March 2017}} {{BLP sources|date=March 2017}} {{orphan|date=March 2017}} }} {{Infobox person |name = Alexey G. Komissarov |image = |office = Industrial Development Fund |occupation = Director |birth_date = {{birth date|1969|10|20}} |place_of_birth = Moscow, Russia |alma_mater = Moscow Automobile and Road University |website = komissarov.com/index |citizenship = Russian |religion = |signature = |footnotes = }}
'''Alexey G. Komissarov''' ({{lang-ru|link=no| Алексей Геннадьевич Комиссаров }}) (born October 20, 1969, Moscow, Russia.) – Russian entrepreneur, Vice-Rector of the [[Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration]] (RANEPA) and the Director of the Graduate School of Public Administration at the RANEPA, ex-Minister of the [[Government of Moscow]].
== Education ==
In 1994 graduated the [[:ru:Московский автомобильно-дорожный государственный технический университет|Moscow Automobile and Road University]] with maintenance and vehicles repair [[Engineer's degree|engineering degree]]. Thеn in 2003 he received an MBA from [[Kingston University]], United Kingdom.<ref>[http://www.kingston.ac.uk/alumni/our-alumni/made-in-kingston/profiles/alexey-komissarov/ Alumni profiles Alexey Komissarov]</ref> In 2009–2010 studied at the London [[Institute of Directors]] (IoD) for the Chartered Director Program.
== Biography ==
In 1993 Komissarov founded "Car-repair system",<ref name="IOD1">{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=Как не поссориться с партнером по бизнесу |url=http://www.forbes.ru/svoi-biznes-opinion/predprinimateli/58151-kak-ne-possoritsya-s-partnerom-po-biznesu |work=журнал "Forbes" |publisher=международная медиа группа ACMG|date=October 12, 2010 |accessdate=2017-03-09 }}</ref> company, specializing in the computerized selection of automotive paints
In 2008 became the winner of the project "Personnel reserve – Professional team of the country", and was included in the government reserve project from Moscow.
Since 2009 – teaches a set of lectures on [[Entrepreneurship]] in [[Kingston University]] and the [[Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration|Academy of National Economy]] as a part of joint [[MBA]] program under [[Government of Russia|Government of the Russian Federation]].
2010 – opened a paint factory in [[Tver]] that uses modern innovative technology production of high quality automotive and industrial paints,<ref>[http://www.paintfactory.ru/en/about-us/company Tver Paint Factory. About us]</ref>
In May 2010 – founded (together with [[Vladimir Aleksandrovich Mau|Vladimir Mau]]) and headed the [[:ru:InCube|InCube]] ([[Business incubator]]) at the Academy of National Economy –.<ref name="InCube1">{{cite news |first=Елена |last=Тимохина |authorlink= |author2= |title=Пять лучших российских бизнес-инкубаторов |url=http://www.forbes.ru/svoi-biznes/startapy/59358-pyat-luchshih-rossiiskih-biznes-inkubatorov |work=Forbes |publisher=ЗАО "Аксель Шпрингер Раша" |date=November 10, 2010 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref><ref name="InCube2">{{cite news |first=Павел |last=Каныгин |authorlink= |author2= |title="Силиконовый подвал" |url=http://www.novayagazeta.ru/society/283.html |work="Новая газета" |publisher=АНО "РИД "Новая газета" |date=December 22, 2010 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref><ref name="InCube3">{{cite news |first=Елена |last=Тимохина |authorlink= |author2= |title=Рисковое дело. Зачем предприниматели вкладывают деньги в чужие проекты на старте? |url=http://www.forbes.ru/svoi-biznes/startapy/61909-riskovoe-delo |work=Forbes |publisher=ЗАО "Аксель Шпрингер Раша" |date=January 13, 2011 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref> Member of the independent directors Association (IDA)<ref>[http://www.ey.com/ru/en/about-us/corporate-responsibility/the-independent-directors-association--ida- Independent Directors Association (IDA)]</ref> and the National Association of Business Angels (SBAR).<ref>[http://www.russba.ru/language/en/ The National Union of business angels]</ref> He was an active angel investor with investments in at least ten start-ups.<ref name="sbar2">{{cite news |first=Алексей |last=Лоссан |authorlink= |author2= |title=Ангельские инвестиции |url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/2303945 |work=газета "Коммерсантъ" – приложение "Review "Форум Сочи 2013" |publisher=АО "Коммерсантъ" |date=September 25, 2013 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref>
On November 25, 2010, Komissarov won [[Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award|Entrepreneur of the Year]] 2010" in the Industrial production category<ref name="concours">{{cite news |first=Екатерина |last=Дранкина |authorlink= |author2= |title=Конкурс редких и исчезающих |url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc/1549064 |work=газета "Коммерсантъ" – приложение "Деньги" |publisher=АО "Коммерсантъ" |date=October 6, 2010 |accessdate=2017-03-09 }}</ref> at "[[Ernst & Young]]" Russian stage international competition.
On February 7, 2011, became head of the Department of "Small and Medium Business support and development" in the [[Government of Moscow|Moscow city Government]]<ref name="deppr1">{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=Собянин назначил нового куратора малого и среднего бизнеса |url=http://www.interfax-russia.ru/Moscow/main.asp?id=208844 |work=Агентство "Интерфакс-Россия" |publisher=ЗАО "Интерфакс" |date=February 8, 2011 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref>..
2011, June, – Department for Small and Medium Business support and development merged with Department of Science and Industrial Policy, Alexey Komissarov appointed as a Head of the Joint Department of Science, Industrial Policy and Entrepreneurship of Moscow city, Russia.<ref name="depna1">{{cite news |first=Любовь |last=Проценко |authorlink= |author2= |title=В правительстве Москвы создан новый департамент |url=http://www.rg.ru/2011/06/07/departament-site-anons.html |work="Российская газета" |publisher=ФГБУ "Редакция "Российской газеты" |date=June 7, 2011 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref><ref name="depna2">{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=С. Собянин уволил главу Департамента науки и промышленной политики Москвы |url=http://www.rbc.ru/rbcfreenews/20110711112358.shtml |work=ИА "РосБизнесКонсалтинг" |publisher=ОАО "РБК" |date=July 11, 2011 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref>
2012 – took part in drafting the law for "Scientific, technical and innovative activity in Moscow city." [[Moscow City Duma]] adopted it as a Moscow city law on June 6, 2012. This law established support by the State for science, technology and innovation. This law stands for the creation of techno parks and techno polis system.<ref name="tech1">{{cite news |first=Людмила |last=Столетнева |authorlink= |author2= |title=Принят закон об инновационной деятельности в столице |url=http://duma.mos.ru/ru/37/news/novosti/prinyat-zakon-ob-innovatsionnoy-deyatelnosti-v-stolitse |work=Официальный сайт Московской городской думы |publisher= |date=June 6, 2012 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref><ref name="tech2">{{cite news |first=Анастасия |last=Гаврилюк |authorlink= |author2= |title=Москва одобряет технопарки |url=http://www.tdaily.ru/news/top-novosti/29583 |work=ИА TelecomDaily |publisher= |date=May 28, 2013 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref><ref name="tech3">{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=Власти Москвы облегчат налоговый режим для технопарков |url=http://polit.ru/news/2012/12/18/jump_zakon_tehnopark/ |work=Полит.ру |publisher= |date=December 18, 2012 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref>
2013 – received [[Kingston University]] (UK) degree of honorary Doctorate for his outstanding contribution to the development of entrepreneur's movement.
On September 17, 2013 was appointed as Minister in the [[Government of Moscow]],<ref name="min1">{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=С.Собянин правительству Москвы: Нужно работать с удвоенной энергией |url=http://top.rbc.ru/politics/17/09/2013/877413.shtml |work=ИА "РосБизнесКонсалтинг" |publisher=ОАО "РБК" |date=September 17, 2013 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref><ref name="min2">{{cite news |first=Августин |last=Северин |authorlink= |author2= |title=Алексей Комиссаров: "Нам важно, чтобы бизнесу в Москве и в России работалось легче" |url=http://vm.ru/news/2013/09/17/aleksej-komissarov-nam-vazhno-chtobi-biznesu-v-moskve-i-v-rossii-rabotalos-legche-214208.html |work=газета "Вечерняя Москва" |publisher=OAO Редакция газеты "Вечерняя Москва" |date=September 17, 2013 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref><ref name="min3">{{cite news |first=Любовь |last=Проценко |authorlink= |author2= |title=Собянин опроверг слухи |url=http://www.rg.ru/2013/09/17/pravitelstvo-site.html |work="Российская газета" |publisher=ФГБУ "Редакция "Российской газеты" |date=September 17, 2013 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref><ref name="mper1">{{cite news |first=Жанна |last=Авязова |authorlink= |author2= |title="Я сам был бизнес-ангелом" |url=http://mperspektiva.ru/topics/1392 |work=газета "Московская перспектива" |publisher=Комплекс градостроительной политики и строительства города Москвы |date=February 11, 2014 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref>
In September 2014 became an adviser to [[Sergey Sobyanin]], [[Mayor of Moscow|Moscow city Mayor]].(resigned as head of the Department of Science, Industrial Policy and Entrepreneurship of Moscow city).
In March 2015 – appointed as the head the Department of Entrepreneurial Leadership at Moscow [[Skolkovo Moscow School of Management|"Skolkovo" Management School]].<ref name="skol2">{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=Цифрыю События |url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/newspaper/articles/2015/03/05/tsifri-sobitiya |work=газета "Ведомости" |publisher=ЗАО "Бизнес Ньюс Медиа" |date=March 5, 2015 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref><ref name="skol3">{{cite news |first=Элина |last=Асфаганова |authorlink= |author2= |title=Алексей Комиссаров возглавил кафедру в Бизнес-школе Сколково |url=http://rusbase.com/news/komissarov-v-shkole/ |work=интернет-издание rusbase.com |publisher= |date=March 4, 2015 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref> In this position, Alexey Komissarov provides interaction of all elements of the Business School ecosystem; business community and its members; alumni organizations, such as Club of investors and Association of mentors of [[Skolkovo Moscow School of Management|Skolkovo Business school]].
On March 18, 2015 – Director of the Industrial Development Fund.<ref name="Komissarov2">{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=Фонд развития промышленности возглавит Алексей Комиссаров |url=http://minpromtorg.gov.ru/press-centre/all/#!fond_razvitiya_promyshlennosti_vozglavit_aleksey_komissarov |work=Официальный сайт Министерства промышленности и торговли РФ |publisher=2015-03-18 |date= |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref><ref name="Komissarov3">{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=Фонд развития промышленности возглавит Алексей Комиссаров |url=http://www.asi.ru/news/34141/ |work=Официальный сайт Агентства стратегических инициатив по продвижению новых проектов (АСИ) |publisher= |date=March 18, 2015 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref> Fund was established after reorganization of the Russian Foundation for Technological Development. There were more than 800 applications submitted for this competition.<ref name="bai2">{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=Алексей Комиссаров возглавит Фонд развития промышленности |url=http://www.deloros.ru/aleksej-komissarov-vozglavit-fond-razvitiya-promyshlennosti.html |work=сайт Общероссийской общественной организации "Деловая Россия" |publisher= |date=March 19, 2015 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref>
On June 3, 2015 – became an independent director in the board of directors at JSC "[[GLONASS]]".<ref name="glon1">{{cite news |first=Игорь |last=Королёв |authorlink= |author2= |title=Созданный Путиным ГЛОНАСС-оператор начинает работать |url=http://www.cnews.ru/news/top/index.shtml?2015/06/05/596303 |work=интернет-издание cnews.ru |publisher=ОАО "РБК" |date=June 5, 2015 |accessdate=2015-08-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150804013359/http://www.cnews.ru/news/top/index.shtml?2015%2F06%2F05%2F596303 |archive-date=August 4, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Before this, in early 2015 he was seriously considered by experts, as one of the main contenders to be the head of JSC "[[GLONASS]]".
April 6, 2017 - appointed Vice-Rector of the [[Russian Presidential Academy of National Economy and Public Administration]] (RANEPA) and the Director of the Graduate School of Public Administration at the RANEPA <ref name=RANHiGS>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title= Алексей Комиссаров стал проректором Президентской академии|url=http://www.ranepa.ru/sobytiya/novosti/prorektorom-prezidentskoj-akademii-stal-aleksej-komissarov |work=сайт RANEPA.RU|publisher= |date=2017-04-07 |accessdate=2017-04-07 }}</ref>
== Public, expert activity == Actively participate in the work of public associations and various expert groups under state agencies<ref>{{cite news|first=|last=|authorlink=|author2=|title=Общественный совет|url=http://www.rupto.ru/about/consult/public_sovet/komissarov?x&starblind=100|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312043850/http://www.rupto.ru/about/consult/public_sovet/komissarov?x&starblind=100|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2017-03-12|work=сайт Федеральной службы по интеллектуальной собственности|publisher=|date=|accessdate=2017-03-09}}</ref>
* Council of the [[Internet Initiatives Development Fund]] (from 2015) * Analysis, research and organization of expert discussions of the [[Fourth Industrial Revolution]] (from 2015)<ref name= "revolution">{{cite news |first=Алексей |last=Комиссаров |authorlink= |author2= |title=Четвертая промышленная революция |url=http://www.vedomosti.ru/opinion/articles/2015/10/14/612719-promishlennaya-revolyutsiya|work=газета "Ведомости" |publisher= |date=October 13, 2015 |accessdate=2017-03-09 }}</ref><ref name="mask" >{{cite news |first=Сергей | last=Медведев |authorlink= |author2= |title=Инвестор в будущее |url=http://www.svoboda.org/a/27949776.html |work=Радио Свобода, Русская служба |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2016-08-27 }}</ref> * member of The Board of Trustees of the All-Russian Public Organization of Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises "OPORA RUSSIA" (since 2016 г.).<ref>[http://bsaward.ru/jury/ Попечительский совет проекта Территория бизнеса — территория жизни]</ref> This organization is one of the founders of the "Business Success" national award, and the best municipal support of entrepreneurship competition<ref>[http://www.bsaward.ru/news/detail.php?news_ID=219864 В Москве названы имена лучших предпринимателей по версии Национальной премии «Бизнес-Успех»]</ref><ref>[https://www.facebook.com/bissuccess.award/?pnref=story Национальная предпринимательская премия «Бизнес-Успех»]</ref> * Supervisory Board of "Agency for Technology Development" (since 2016)<ref>[http://www.startlr.com/in-russia-created-the-agency-for-technological-development/ In Russia, created the Agency for Technological Development]</ref> * member of Interdepartmental Commission for Technological Development under the President of the [[Russian Federation]] Council for Economic Modernization and Innovative Development of Russia (since 2016) * Interdepartmental Commission for the [[Russian Federation]] Innovative Development Strategy implementation till 2020 of the Russian Federation Council for Economic Modernization and Innovative Development of Russia (since 2016) * Launch of the educational project ipi 4.0 (since 2017)<ref name="ipi4.0i" >{{cite news |first=Лариса |last=Константинова |authorlink= |author2= |title=Фонд развития промышленности запускает просветительский проект ipi 4.0|url=https://4science.ru/news/FRP-zapuskaet-prosvetitelskii-proekt-po-chetvertoi-promishlennoi-revolucii |work=сайт 4science |publisher= |date=February 2, 2017 |accessdate= }}</ref>
== Hobbies ==
He participated in Russian and European motorcycle championships. Teamed up with Alexander Kuznetsov, Alexey Komissarov took first place in the Endurance Cup of Russia in 2008.<ref name="moto1">{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |author2= |title=ШКМГ: Официальный отчет о финальном этапе Кубка России по Эндуранс |url=http://www.motogonki.ru/russbk/russbk_20080910_231203.html |work=интернет-сайт motogonki.ru |publisher= |date=September 10, 2008 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref> In March 2015, he took part in one of the 20 most extreme races of the world – [[Lake Baikal|Baikal]] Ice [[Marathon]] (42 km on the ice of lake Baikal in [[Siberia]] from one bank to another)<ref name="bai1">{{cite news |first=Елена |last=Николаева |authorlink= |author2= |title=Марафонский бег стал новым трендом у российской элиты |url=http://www.mk.ru/social/2015/02/26/marafonskiy-beg-stal-novym-trendom-u-rossiyskoy-elity.html |work=газета "Московский комсомолец" |publisher=ЗАО "Редакция газеты "Московский Комсомолец" |date=February 26, 2015 |accessdate=2015-08-28 }}</ref> and finished second in his age category.<ref name="bai3">{{cite news |first=Василий |last=Фокин |authorlink= |author2= |title="Я перестал ненавидеть бег после Байкальского марафона". Алексей Комиссаров" |url=http://adidas-running.ru/articles/intervju-s-alekseem-komissarovym |work=интернет-сайт adidas-running.ru |publisher=ООО "Адидас" |date=August 6, 2015 |accessdate=2015-08-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910002705/http://adidas-running.ru/articles/intervju-s-alekseem-komissarovym |archive-date=September 10, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Now he is doing [[Triathlon]], in 2016 finished two [[Ironman Triathlon|IronMan races]] (in South Africa and Spain)<ref>[http://komissarov.com/blog/ironman-south-africa-26-01-2016 Отчёт о моем первом Айроне — гонке IronMan South Africa]</ref> He enjoys motorbike racing, photography, diving, swimming, pentathlon, skiing and boxing
== Family ==
He is married and has three daughters.
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{Philippine name|Planta|Tugade}} {{Infobox Officeholder | name = Arthur Tugade | image = Arthur Tugade - 2018 (cropped).jpg | image_size = | caption = Tugade in 2018 | office = [[Secretary of Transportation (Philippines)|Secretary of Transportation]] | term_start = June 30, 2016 | term_end = | president = [[Rodrigo Duterte]] | predecessor = [[Joseph Emilio Abaya]] | successor = | office2 = President and CEO of Clark Development Corporation | predecessor2 = Felipe Antonio Remollo | successor2 = Eliseo B. Santiago (OIC) | term_start2 = December 18, 2012 | term_end2 = April 26, 2016 | president2 = [[Benigno Aquino III]] | party = | birth_name = Arthur Planta Tugade | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1946|01|09}} | birth_place = [[Claveria, Cagayan|Claveria]], [[Cagayan]], [[Commonwealth of the Philippines|Philippine Commonwealth]] | nationality = [[Filipino people|Filipino]] | occupation = [[Businessman]] | profession = [[Politician]] | residence = | alma_mater = [[San Beda College]] | spouse = Maria Soledad Maddela Tugade | children = | religion = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Arthur "Art" Planta Tugade''' (born January 9, 1946){{cite web|url=http://specials.sunstar.com.ph/thepresident/cabinet/ |title=Cabinet – DuterteWatch |publisher=[[Sun.Star]] |accessdate=11 August 2016}} is a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] businessman and lawyer from [[Cagayan]]. He is the current [[Secretary of Transportation (Philippines)|Secretary]] of the [[Department of Transportation (Philippines)|Department of Transportation]] after being appointed by President [[Rodrigo Duterte]] to replace [[Joseph Emilio Abaya]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/133225-duterte-tugade-dotc-dominguez-finance |title=Duterte names Tugade for DOTC, eyes Dominguez for DOF |publisher=[[Rappler]] |date=16 May 2016 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} He previously held the position of President and Chief Executive Officer of Clark Development Corporation, an attached agency of the [[government-owned and controlled corporation|government-owned]] [[Bases Conversion and Development Authority]] under President [[Benigno Aquino III]]. == Early life and education == Tugade was born on January 9, 1946 to poor parents from [[Claveria, Cagayan|Claveria]], Cagayan, Francisco Tugade and Lucefina Planta.{{cite web|url=http://business.inquirer.net/105527/new-cdc-chief-tackles-changes-in-cultural-financial-fronts |title=New CDC chief tackles changes in cultural, financial fronts |author=Orejas, T. |publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=2 February 2013 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} His parents were both employed at the Public Works Department and he was in elementary school when they moved to [[Sampaloc, Manila]]. Tugade attended law school at the [[San Beda College of Law]] where he was classmates with President Rodrigo Duterte. He graduated ''magna cum laude'' in 1971. He completed his post-graduate studies at the [[National University of Singapore]] under the NUS-Stanford Executive Program in 1985.{{cite web|url=http://interaksyon.com/article/127833/dutertes-art-tugade--the-next-dotc-chief-is-a-slum-dweller-turned-businessman-lawyer |title=Duterte's Art Tugade: Will the slum dweller-turned-businessman-lawyer become the next DOTC chief? |author=Sabangan, A.C. |publisher=[[Interaksyon]] |date=17 May 2016 |accessdate=25 June 2016}} == Career and businesses == Tugade engaged in private law practice before joining government service. He was a partner at Bengzon, Verano, Tugade and Escolin Law Office. He also pursued a career in global logistics, information technology, tourism and consumer products business serving as chairman and president of several firms, including Transnational Diversified Group, Yusen Air and Sea Services, TDG Asia Corporation, Harmony Organic Farms, and Easycall Communications.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/Research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=11501125&privcapId=20726983&previousCapId=20726983&previousTitle=Clark%20Development%20Corp. |title=Arthur P. Tugade: Executive Profile and Biography |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |accessdate=25 June 2016}} Tugade founded Perry's Realty, named after his son who died from asthma attack at age 12. The company grew to become Perry's Holding Corporation which employs more than 350 employees in 10 corporations of the Perry's Group of Companies which include Transglobal Equipment Leasing, Perry's Technology, ATP Travel, Perryome, Transglobal Trucking and Transglobal Consolidators, Inc. == References == {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Joseph Emilio Abaya]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Secretary of Transportation (Philippines)|Secretary of Transportation]]|years=2016–present}} {{s-inc}} |- {{s-prec}} {{s-bef|before=[[Bernadette Romulo-Puyat]]|as=[[Secretary of Tourism (Philippines)|Secretary of Tourism]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Philippine order of precedence|Order of Precedence of the Philippines]]
{{small|''as [[Secretary of Transportation (Philippines)|Secretary of Transportation]]}}}} {{s-aft|after=[[Fortunato dela Peña]]|as=[[Secretary of Science and Technology (Philippines)|Secretary of Science and Technology]]}} {{s-end}} {{Duterte Cabinet}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tugade, Arthur}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Filipino lawyers]] [[Category:Filipino businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Secretaries of Transportation of the Philippines]] [[Category:Heads of government-owned and controlled corporations of the Philippines]] [[Category:People from Cagayan]] [[Category:People from Sampaloc, Manila]] [[Category:People from Quezon City]] [[Category:San Beda University alumni]] [[Category:Benigno Aquino III Administration personnel]] [[Category:Duterte Administration cabinet members]]

{{BLP sources|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Audu Maikori | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1975|8|13}} | birth_place = [[Kaduna]], [[Kaduna State]], Nigeria | nationality = [[Nigerian]] | education = [[University of Jos]]
[[Nigerian Law School]]
[[MIT Sloan School of Management]] | alma_mater = [[King's College, Lagos]] | occupation = Lawyer, entrepreneur, social activist, public speaker, creative industry professional, founder and President of the [[Chocolate City (music label)|Chocolate City]] | years_active = 2001-present | known_for = [[Nigerian Idol]], [[Chocolate City (music label)|Chocolate City Music]] | notable_works = [[Chocolate City (music label)|Chocolate City Group]] | awards = [[#Achievements|see below]] }} '''Audu Maikori''' (born 13 August 1975, [[Kaduna]]) is a Nigerian lawyer, entrepreneur, social activist, public speaker and creative industry professional. He is the founder and Group CEO of the [[Chocolate City (music label)|Chocolate City Entertainment]].{{cite web|title=Phones ring up millions for Nigerian musicians|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/06/09/news/nigeria-ring-back-tone-musicians/|website=[[CNN]]|publisher=Eleni Giokos|accessdate=5 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=Changing the Script of Reality Shows with Chocolate City’s Unsigned|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2016/03/27/changing-the-script-of-reality-shows-with-chocolate-citys-unsigned/|website=This Day|accessdate=5 October 2016}} He is well known as Founder of [[Chocolate City (music label)|Chocolate City]], Entertainment lawyer and regarded as the "[[Simon Cowell]]" in [[Nigerian Idol]]'s first season. He won multiple awards during his career, including the [[International Young Music Entrepreneur of the Year]] award in 2007.{{cite web|title=Creative Economy people|url=http://creativeconomy.britishcouncil.org/people/audu-maikori/|website=[[British Council]]|accessdate=5 October 2016}} ==Early life and education== Audu Maikori was born in Kaduna State to Adamu Maikori and Laiatu Gyet Maude. He was raised in [[Lagos]] and attended Adrao International School and [[King's College, Lagos|King's College]] before obtaining his Law degree from the [[University of Jos]] in 1999. He later obtained his Bachelor of Laws (B.L) from the [[Nigerian Law School|Law school]] Abuja.[http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/making-chocolate-products/73268/ Making Chocolate Products] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720075500/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/making-chocolate-products/73268/ |date=20 July 2011 }} He is an alumnus of the [[M.I.T]] [[Sloan School of Management]] Boston. ==Career== ===Early entertainment career=== In 1997, Audu and his friends at the [[University of Jos]] started discussing the possibilities of setting up a club. After a debate on the name of club, Audu suggested naming the club ''Chocolate City'' Chocolate City became the biggest rave around the Universities in northern Nigeria.{{cite web|title=Audu Maikori Covers The Latest Issue Of THISDAY Style|url=http://jaguda.com/2015/08/24/audu-maikori-covers-the-latest-issue-of-thisday-style/|website=Jaguda.com|accessdate=5 October 2016}} ===The Guild of Artistes and Poets (GAP)=== During his National Youth Service Corps (NYSC) program Audu and his friend named Paul Okeugo founded the ''Guild of Artistes and Poets'' (GAP), a [[non-profit]] arts society. The GAP held its first meeting in April 2001. The GAP formed strategic alliances with the Ministry of Culture and Tourism, the [[British Council]] and held art exhibitions in partnership with the French Cultural Centre. The GAP expanded its reach to Jos, Plateau State and in Lagos. By 2005 the GAP had over 300 active members. ===Legal career=== Audu was called to the [[Nigerian Bar Association]] in January 2001 and started his legal career working as an Associate with the litigation-inclined firm of Chief Afe Babalola SAN & Co where he worked from 2001 to 2003. He worked as legal advisor to leasing company of Nigeria (a subsidiary of Bank of Industry), and company secretary of Abuja Markets Management Limited. In 2006, Maikori was appointed Senior Legal consultant with CPCS Transcom International, where he worked on the legal and regulatory aspects of privatization transactions including the Nigeria Ports Authority, Nigerian Railway Corporation, unbundling and privatization of [[NEPA|PHCN]]. He represented Nigeria in the [[International Institute for the Unification of Private Law|UNIDROIT]] Sub-Committee of governmental experts for the preparation of a preliminary draft Protocol to the [[Convention on International Interests in Mobile Equipment]] on Matters specific to Space Assets in 2005. In May 2007, Maikori co-organized the first Nigerian International Music Summit in March 2007. Over 400 music industry stakeholders drawn from all over Nigeria attended the event. Maikori is a member of the [[Chartered Institute of Arbitrators]] UK, International Association of Entertainment Lawyers, the [[Nigerian Bar Association]] and [[International Bar Association]] (IBA). In 2002, he along with his brother [[Yahaya Maikori]] started ''Law Allianz'', a firm of legal practitioners based in Lagos and Abuja. He was selected as lead legal consultant for key national infrastructure projects including the Lagos Rail Mass Transit project (2008), Abuja Mass Transit project (2006-2008) and Kano Mass transit project in 2011. In March 2015, Audu resigned from 'Law Allianz' to concentrate on other business affairs. ===Chocolate City=== [[Chocolate City (music label)|Chocolate City Limited]] was registered in October 2003 but commenced business in 2005. Audu partnering with Paul Okeugo and his brother [[Yahaya Maikori]] as directors of the company. Later that year he alongside Paul Okeugo and two other partners produced first event under 'Chocolate City' banner in partnership with [[British American Tobacco]], which held at the [[University of Maiduguri]]. Audu was introduced to a song called ''Na Ba Ka'' by an artist named Jeremiah Gyang's by label Six Foot Plus. In January 2005, Chocolate City signed Jeremiah Gyang under a recording and management contract and re-released the album 'Na Ba Ka'. In mid 2006, [[M.I Abaga|M.I]] was signed up to Chocolate City. In 2012, after a corporate restructure, Chocolate City Group was formed with renowned businessman and lawyer [[Hakeem Bello-Osagie]] joining the board as Chairman. Four companies were formed to constitute the group namely Chocolate City Music, Chocolate City Media, Chocolate City Distribution and STM with Audu appointed as President of the Group. In March 2015, Audu announced the return of [[Jesse Jagz]] to Chocolate City. On 31 June 2015 Audu via Twitter announced his exit as CEO of Chocolate City Music and the appointment of [[M.I Abaga|M.I]] as the new CEO of Chocolate City Music, with label mate [[Ice Prince Zamani]] as the Vice President of the music label. Audu also announced the objectives for the 3 Chocolate City subsidiaries to include radio, television and film. On 30 June 2015, Audu resigned as CEO of [[Chocolate City Music]]{{cite web|title=Audu Maikori Steps Down as CEO of Chocolate City after 10 Years!|url=https://www.bellanaija.com/2015/04/audu-maikori-steps-down-as-ceo-of-chocolate-city-after-10-years/|website=Bella Naija|accessdate=5 October 2016}} handing the reigns to former vice president of the label, [[M.I Abaga|M.I]].{{cite web|title=M.I Abaga succeeds Audu Maikori as CEO of Africa's biggest record label|url=http://pulse.ng/buzz/chocolate-city-m-i-abaga-succeeds-audu-maikori-as-ceo-of-africas-biggest-record-label-id3924406.html|website=Pulse.ng|publisher=Joey Akan|accessdate=5 October 2016}} [[Ice Prince]] was made the new vice president of Chocolate City.{{cite web|title=Chocolate City names M.I Abaga as Audu Maikori’s successor|url=http://thenet.ng/2015/06/chocolate-city-names-m-i-abaga-as-audu-maikoris-successor/|website=NET|publisher=Adedayo Odulaja|accessdate=5 October 2016}}. In March 2018, Chocolate City launched CCX Lounge- a live music venue and lounge located at the prestigious Jabi Lake Mall, in Abuja. The 400 capacity venue is purpose-built for live music and its decor has been hailed as authentic Afro Nigerian by Mode Men Magazine. ===Activism=== Maikori has received commendations for his work in developing the youth including being invited to Albania in 2008 to deliver a keynote speech at a seminar organized by the Albania Ministry of Youth and Employment, Minister of culture and [[British Council]]. In 2010, Maikori was part of the ''Enough is Enough'' campaign which saw thousands of Nigerians protest against issues. In a four-hour protest, they marched to the National Assembly in [[Abuja]]. Maikori became the face of ''Enough is Enough'' after a police officer warned him to back down or be shot; Maikori refused to back down. He later led the other protesters to march on peacefully to make their protests heard by the National Assembly.{{cite web|title=We Must Walk The Walk, Not Just Talk The Talk|url=http://www.thenet.ng/2011/05/we-must-walk-the-walk-not-just-talk-the-talk/|website=NET|accessdate=5 October 2016}} '''Southern Kaduna killings''' Maikori was very vocal against the Southern Kaduna killings by suspected Fulani herdsmen who killed over 250 men and women of Southern Kaduna origin. He was vocal about the seeming neglect by the Kaduna State Governor and The Federal Government of Nigeria, especially when the Kaduna State Governor Mallam El Rufai admitted to paying Fulani herdsmen compensation to "stop" them from killing the predominantly Christian Southern Kaduna population. In March 2017, he was arrested and arraigned by the Kaduna State (his state of origin) Governor over alleged incitement to violence {{Cite web|url=https://www.bellanaija.com/2017/03/audu-maikori-arraigned-in-kaduna-gets-bail/|title=Audu Maikori Arraigned in Kaduna, Gets Bail - BellaNaija|website=www.bellanaija.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-15}}. On 28th day of October, 2017, the Nigerian media was awash with headlines announcing the victory of Maikori in which forty million (N40,000,000) Naira was awarded to Maikori as damages against the Governor of Kaduna State, Mal. Nasir El-Rufai and the Nigerian Police Force. Maikori had brought a case of unlawful arrest and abuse of his fundamental human rights when Gov. El-Rufai caused his arrest and detention on February 17, 2017 [https://opera.pulse.ng/gist/audu-maikori-choc-city-boss-opens-up-on-being-manhandled-by-the-police-id3524029.html ===National service=== On 13 February 2012, Audu Maikori was appointed to represent Nigerian Youth as a member of the Presidential Committee on the Subsidy Reinvestment and Empowerment Programme (SURE-P), the committee was formed by President [[Goodluck Jonathan]] himself. Maikori was the youngest member of the committee.He was placed in charge of the Graduate Internship Scheme which under his coordination grew the number of employed interns from 1,800 interns in 2013 to 22,000 interns by January 2015. In May 2012 Maikori was elected to serve as a member of the board of COSON. Maikori was one of those behind the lobby for the NCC to officially appoint a CMO to collect royalties for songwriters and performers after 13 years of the NCC failing to settle the dispute between the MCSN and PMRS, both de-registered CMOs which had been embroiled in legal battles for supremacy for years. His appointment has been lauded as the right step in the right direction by music industry stakeholders.{{cite web|title=COSON Selects Board Members – Banky W, Efe Omorogbe, Audu Maikori, Obi Asika, Adewale Ayuba Make the Cut|url=http://www.africamusiclaw.com/industry-news-coson-selects-board-members-banky-w-efe-omorogbe-audu-maikori-obi-asika-adewale-ayuba-make-the-cut/|website=African Music Law|accessdate=5 October 2016}} ===Public speaker=== Maikori is also a public speaker and has traveled widely to speak on entrepreneurship and youth development. He was a speaker at the [[M.I.T]] Legatum Annual conference Visions and Ventures in 2013. In 2014 he was invited to speak at the [[Oxford University]] African Business conference. In 2016, he was selected as a panelist and moderator at [[The Global Africa Investment Summit]] which was hosted by President [[Paul Kagame]] in Kigali, Rwanda. According to [[YNaija]] magazine, Audu is one of the most powerful people's list of 2014 in Nigerian Entertainment in March 2014.{{cite web|title=Nideria: List of the 10 most powerful people in entertainment|url=http://ynaija.com/don-jazzy-audu-maikori-rita-dominic-yes-wizkid-see-the-full-list-of-the-10-most-powerful-people-in-entertainment-ynaijapowerlist/|website=[[YNaija]]|publisher=Wilfred Okiche|accessdate=5 October 2016}} In October 2015, Audu was appointed the Chairman of the Nigerian Digital Music Monitoring Group, associated with organizations [[Nigerian Copyright Commission]], [[Nigerian Communications Commission]], [[National Information Technology Development Agency]], [[National Assembly]] and other relevant bodies to develop specific methods for the implementation of the resolutions of the Summit. ===Nigerian Idol=== In September 2010, Maikori was made judge for the first season of [[Nigerian Idol]] alongside [[Yinka Davies]] and [[Jeffrey Daniel]].{{cite web|title=2010 Nigerian Idol Judges: Jeffrey Daniel, Yinka Davies & Audu Maikori|url=http://ladybrillenigeria.com/2010/09/2010-nigerian-idol-judges-jeffrey-daniel-yinka-davies-audu-maikori.html|website=Ladybrille|accessdate=5 October 2016}} The show proved to be a ratings success, but a year later he left the series to concentrate on other commitments, and was replaced by singer-publisher [[Charly Boy]].[http://nigeriafilms.com/news/13865/23/area-fathercharly-boy-replaces-audu-maikori-as-jud.html Charly Boy Nigerian Idol] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120104193853/http://nigeriafilms.com/news/13865/23/area-fathercharly-boy-replaces-audu-maikori-as-jud.html |date=4 January 2012 }} ==Achievements== ===Awards & accolades=== * [[International Young Music Entrepreneur of the Year]] 2007 (Nigeria) * [[International Young Music Entrepreneur of the Year]] 2007 (Global Winner) * Entertainment Executive of the year 2011 by the Nigerian Entertainment Award (NEA) * Award for outstanding award in Music and Entertainment by the National Youth Merit Awards 2011 * Young Entrepreneur of the Year (2011) – Diaspora Professionals Award 2011 * Mentor of the Year – 2010- Enterprise Foundation) * Creative Entrepreneur of the Year for Music – 2011- CIAN * Winner – African Awards for Entrepreneurship 2011 * Entertainment Executive of the Year – 2012- Nigerian Reunion Corporation * SME Leader Award- 2014 by Fidelity Bank * National Youth Merit Award in Entertainment – NYMA 2012 * Award for Excellence – Nigerian Law School Class of 2013 * Award for Leadership in Governance – Junior Chambers International (JCI) -2013 * Enterprise Award for Entertainment - Southern Kaduna Peoples Union(SOKAPU) 2015 * City People Magazine Special Recognition for outstanding contribution to the Nigerian music industry (2011, 2015 and 2016) In 2008, at the inaugural edition of the United Kingdom Young Music Entrepreneur, Maikori was nominated to serve as a judge alongside four other British music industry judges, making him the African judge in the history of the competition. On 29 June 2007, he won the [[International Young Music Entrepreneur of the Year]] (IYMEY) for his work with Chocolate City beating off international competition from Egypt, India, Indonesia, Latvia, Lithuania, Malaysia, Philippines, Poland and Tanzania. He received special judges commendation as well as $15,000 Dollars in prize money. In December 2011, Chocolate City Group, under Audu’s leadership, was named winner at the prestigious Africa Awards for Entrepreneurship in Nairobi, Kenya. Chocolate City was selected from over 3,300 applicants from 48 African countries to win prize of $50,000. In November 2014, he was inducted as a Fellow of the Nigerian Leadership Institute(NLI) in November at the NLI-[[YALE]] Leadership Conference which held at the campus in [[New Haven]]. ===Fellowships=== *Fellow – ''Nigerian Leadership Institute'' (NLI) *Life Fellow – ''Guild of Artistes and Poets'' (GAP) *Honorary Fellow – ''Institute of Chartered Portfolio Management Nigeria'' ===Judge=== Audu has served as judge on numerous entrepreneurship and innovation competitions both locally and internationally which include:- *[[M.I.T]] Inclusive Innovation Competition - 2018 *[[Chivas Regal|Chivas]] The Venture Competition - 2015 and 2016 *[[Etisalat Prize for Innovation]]- 2012,2013,2014 and 2015 *[[Microsoft]] Passion to Empire Competition- 2015 *[[SheLeads Africa]] -2014 *[[British Council]] International Young Fashion Entrepreneur of the Year - 2009 *[[British Council]] International Young Music Entrepreneur of the Year - 2008 & 2009 *[[British Council]] United Kingdom Young Music Entrepreneur of the Year - 2008 ==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite web|title=Music and money (Interview)|url=https://www.reuters.com/video/2007/10/27/music-and-money?videoId=69607|website=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=5 October 2016}} ==External links== * {{Twitter|Audu}} * [http://creativeconomy.britishcouncil.org/people/audu-maikori/ Audu Maikori] on [[British Council]] {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Chocolate City Music}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maikori, Audu}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Nigerian businesspeople]] [[Category:Nigerian lawyers]] [[Category:University of Jos alumni]] [[Category:1975 births]]

{{Orphan|date=September 2018}}
{{Infobox person | name = Badruddin Ahmad | image = 1-mmscan0002.jpg | caption = Badruddin Ahmad circa 1935 | birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1912|8|17}} | birth_place = [[Patiala]], [[India]] | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1981|3|19|1912|8|17}} | death_place = [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]] | death_cause = | alma_mater = [[Allahabad University]] | occupation = Civil Aviator }}
'''Badruddin Ahmad''' (17 August 1912, Patiala, India - 19 March 1981, Karachi, Pakistan) was a pioneer in the field of [[Civil aviation]]. He was instrumental in the development of post-[[Second World War|World War II]] aviation plans and supervised the construction of non-military runways and airports.<ref>http://www.manimasood.com/civil-aviation-pioneer/</ref> The assets developed by Ahmad were transferred to the international civil authorities, leading to the advent of Civil Aviation as an industry.
Ahmad was perhaps best known for his association with the [[International Civil Aviation Organization]] (ICAO) and in his roles as the Director General of Civil Aviation for the [[Government of Pakistan]] and Chief of Administration at the [[Pakistan Meteorological Department]].
==Education==
Ahmad graduated with a Master of Arts in Mathematics degree, with specialization in Advanced Astronomy from [[Allahabad University]] (then called 'University of Allahbad' and referred to as 'the Oxford of the East')<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/1106781.cms Allahabad Varsity to become a central university] [[The Times of India]], May 11, 2005.</ref> on 30 January 1935.
==Career==
Badruddin Ahmed was instrumental in the events and planning that lead to the advent of the Civil Aviation industry.
He drafted government policy on the [[subsidization]] of flying clubs; licensed many non-military pilots, navigators and ground engineers; and progressed the selection and training of pilots and ground engineers for the [[Royal Indian Air Force]].
After [[Pakistan Movement|partition of Indian subcontinent]], Ahmed drafted the plans for Civil Aviation in Pakistan and conducted pioneer work in establishing the Department of Civil Aviation in Pakistan and was responsible for the coordination of the department's activities and international relations.
He was responsible for much work in the establishment of [[Pakistan International Airlines]] and was director in charge of the construction of various civil aviation works such as jet [[runways]] and [[airports]].
In 1955 he was elected member of the British [[Chartered Institute of Logistics and Transport|Institute of Transport]]. He was elected Chairman in 1959 by unanimous vote of the Joint Middle East and South East Asia Air Navigation Conference to lay down the rules for [[Jet Aircraft]] operations.
In 1959, he was awarded the [[Tamgha-e-Quaid-e-Azam]], a prestigious [[Civil decorations of Pakistan|civil decoration of Pakistan]], for his contribution to the Civil Aviation development in Pakistan.
In 1960 he was promoted to Director General of Civil Aviation Authority.
In 1962 he was given the additional appointment of Chief of Administration with the status of Additional Director in the Pakistan Meteorological Department.
During his career he represented Pakistan in four General Assemblies of the International Civil Aviation Organization and worked on defining international travel and carrier routes.
==Horticulture==
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Badruddin Ahmad with Begum Liaqat Ali.jpg|right|thumb|Badruddin Ahmad at a flower show, receiving an award from [[Ra'ana Liaquat Ali Khan|Begum Liaquat Ali]], First Lady of Pakistan.]] -->
In addition to his distinguished career in government policy and Civil Aviation, Ahmad made contributions to the field of [[horticulture]].
He was a fellow of the [[Royal Horticultural Society]] and the Royal Rose Society (now the [[Royal National Rose Society]]). Many [[Introduced species|non-indigenous plants]] in the Indian Subcontinent are attributed to him.
He was co-founder of the Horticultural Society of Pakistan and served as its Vice President from 1959 to 1961. During his tenure he introduced the [[Ficus elastica|rubber plant]] (''Ficus elastica'') to Pakistan and received awards and recognition for [[Crotons]] and [[Carnation]] cultivations.
After death, the [[British High Commission]] suggested that the Government of Pakistan dedicate a [[Botanical and horticultural library|Horticultural Library]] to his name. A one million-pound memorial fund for books was offered. Alas, political turbulence in Pakistan at the time meant that the proposal never came to fruition.
==Personal life==
Ahmad was born in Patiala, India to Khairuddin Ahmad and Fatima Begum Javed. His father was a Royal Veterinary Surgeon and his mother was a homemaker. He is the oldest of five siblings, three sisters and two younger brothers.
A [[polyglot]], Ahmad was able to speak, read and write in [[English language|English]], [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Urdu]] and [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]]; and had working knowledge of [[Italian language|Italian]], [[French language|French]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and other languages.
He participated in the popular ''Brain Trust'' programme on [[Radio Pakistan]], was a member of the [[Royal Photographic Society]], and a lifetime member of the council of the [[Iqbal Academy Pakistan|Iqbal Academy]].
He was married twice to Ms. Jeanne Ahmed and Ms. Maher UnNisah and had two sons, Saeed A Masood and Shafat A Mehmood.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahmad, Badruddin}} [[Category:1912 births]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] [[Category:Civil aviation]] [[Category:Muhajir people]] [[Category:Pakistani businesspeople]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox government agency |agency_name = Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) |nativename = |logo = CSIRO Logo.svg |logo_width = 100px |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |motto = We imagine. We collaborate. We innovate. |headquarters = [[Canberra]], [[Australian Capital Territory]], [[Australia]] |formed = 1916 |preceding1 = Advisory Council of Science and Industry (1916–1920) |preceding2 = Institute of Science and Industry (1920–1926) |preceding3 = CSIR (1926–1949) |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = Australia |employees = 5,565 (2017){{cite web|title=Our People|url=https://www.csiro.au/en/About/Our-impact/Reporting-our-impact/Annual-reports/16-17-annual-report/part3/Our-people|website=CSIRO|accessdate=17 April 2018|date=24 October 2017}} |budget = |minister1_name = [[Michaelia Cash|The Hon Michaelia Cash]] |minister1_pfo = Minister for Jobs and Innovation (Australia) |chief1_name = [[David Thodey]] |chief1_position = [[Chairman|Chair]] |chief2_name = [[Larry R. Marshall]] |chief2_position = [[Chief executive|CE]] |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = [http://www.csiro.au/ CSIRO Australia] |footnotes = }} The '''Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation''' ('''CSIRO''') is an independent [[Government of Australia|Australian federal government]] agency responsible for scientific research. Its chief role is to improve the economic and social performance of industry for the benefit of the community. CSIRO works with leading organisations around the world. From its headquarters in Canberra, CSIRO maintains more than 50 sites across Australia and in France, Chile and the United States, employing about 5500 people. Federally funded scientific research began in Australia {{age|1916|6|1}} years ago. The Advisory Council of Science and Industry was established in 1916 but was hampered by insufficient available finance. In 1926 the research effort was reinvigorated by establishment of the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), which strengthened national science leadership and increased research funding. CSIR grew rapidly and achieved significant early successes. In 1949 further legislated changes included re-naming the organisation as CSIRO. Notable developments by CSIRO have included the invention of [[atomic absorption spectroscopy]], essential components of [[Wi-Fi]] technology, development of the first commercially successful [[polymer banknote]], the invention of the insect repellent in [[Aerogard]] and the introduction of a series of biological controls into Australia, such as the introduction of [[myxomatosis]] and [[rabbit calicivirus]] for the control of [[European rabbit|rabbit]] populations. == Structure == CSIRO is governed by a board appointed by the Australian Government, currently chaired by [[David Thodey]]{{post-nominals|country=AUS|A0}}. There are nine directors inclusive of the Chief Executive, presently Dr. [[Larry R. Marshall|Larry Marshall]], who is responsible for management of the organisation. == Research and focus areas == CSIRO is structured into research focus areas, services and infrastructure. === Research areas === * Agriculture and Food * Data61 (formed from the merger of [[NICTA]] with CSIRO's Digital Productivity Flagship){{cite web |url= https://www.csiro.au/en/News/News-releases/2015/CSIRO-NICTA-join-forces |title= CSIRO and NICTA join forces to create digital research powerhouse |date= 15 August 2015 |publisher= csiro.au }} * Energy * Land and Water * Mineral Resources * Manufacturing * Oceans and Atmosphere * Health and Biosecurity === Services === * Small medium enterprise (SME Connect) * Education * Publishing house ([[CSIRO Publishing]]) * Testing * Strategy and foresight (CSIRO Futures) === Infrastructure and facilities === CSIRO manages national research facilities and scientific infrastructure on behalf of the nation to assist with the delivery of research. The national facilities and specialised laboratories are available to both international and Australian users from industry and research. * [[Australian Animal Health Laboratory]] (AAHL) * [[Australia Telescope National Facility]] - radio telescopes included in the Facility include the [[Australia Telescope Compact Array]], the [[Parkes Observatory]], [[Mopra Observatory]] and the [[Australian Square Kilometre Array Pathfinder]] * [[Canberra Deep Space Communication Complex]] * National Marine Facility, [[RV Investigator]] * [[Pawsey Supercomputing Centre]] === Collections === CSIRO manages a number of collections of animal and plant specimens that contribute to national and international biological knowledge. The National Collections contribute to taxonomic, genetic, agricultural and ecological research. * Australian National Algae Culture Collection * The [[Atlas of Living Australia]] * Australian Tree Seed Centre * Australian National Fish Collection * Australian National Insect Collection * Australian National Herbarium * [[Australian National Wildlife Collection]] == History == ===Evolution of the organisation=== A precursor to CSIRO, the Advisory Council of Science and Industry, was established in 1916 on the initiative of prime minister [[Billy Hughes]]. However, the Advisory Council struggled with insufficient funding during the First World War. In 1920 the Council was renamed the Commonwealth Institute of Science and Industry, and was led by [[George Handley Knibbs]] (1921–26), but continued to struggle financially. In 1926 the [[Parliament of Australia|Australian Parliament]] modified the principal Act for national scientific research (the ''Institute of Science and Industry Act 1920''){{cite act |title= Science and Industry Research Act 1926 |number= 22 |date= 14 September 1920 |url= http://classic.austlii.edu.au/cgi-bin/download.cgi/cgi-bin/download.cgi/download/au/legis/cth/num_act/iosaia1920221920384.pdf |accessdate= 18 April 2018 }} by passing ''The Science and Industry Research Act 1926''.{{cite act |title= Science and Industry Research Act 1926 |number= 20 |date= 21 June 1926 |url= http://www5.austlii.edu.au/cgi-bin/download.cgi/cgi-bin/download.cgi/download/au/legis/cth/num_act/saira1926201926306.pdf |accessdate= 18 April 2018 }} The new Act replaced the Institute with the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR). With encouragement from prime minister [[Stanley Bruce]], strengthened national science leadership and increased research funding, CSIR grew rapidly and achieved significant early successes. The council was structured to represent the federal structure of government in Australia, and had state-level committees and a central council. In addition to an improved structure, CSIR benefited from strong bureaucratic management under [[George Julius]], [[David Rivett]], and Arnold Richardson. Research focused on primary and secondary industries. Early in its existence, CSIR established divisions studying animal health and animal nutrition. After the [[Great Depression]], research was extended into manufacturing and other secondary industries.{{cite web |url= http://csiropedia.csiro.au/our-history/ |title= Our history |author= |date= April 2018 |website= CSIROpedia |publisher= CSIRO |access-date= 16 April 2018 }} In 1949 the Act was changed again{{cite act |title= Science and Industry Research Act 1949 |number= 13 |date= 21 June 1926 |url= https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2012C00352/Download |accessdate= 18 April 2018 }} and the entity name amended to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. The amendment enlarged and reconstituted the organisation and its administrative structure. Under [[Ian Clunies Ross]] as chairman, CSIRO pursued new areas such as radio astronomy and industrial chemistry. CSIRO still operates under the provisions of the 1949 Act in a wide range of scientific inquiry. Since 1949 CSIRO has expanded its activities to almost every field of primary, secondary and tertiary industry, including the environment, human nutrition, conservation, urban and rural planning, and water. It works with leading organisations around the world and maintains more than 50 sites across Australia and in France, Chile and the United States of America, employing about 5500 people.https://www.csiro.au/en/About/International{{cite web|url=http://www.csiro.au/en/About/International |title=International collaboration – CSIRO |website=Csiro.au |date=2016-01-28 |accessdate=2017-01-04}} === Inventions === Notable inventions and breakthroughs by CSIRO include: * A4 DSP chip * [[Aerogard]], insect repellent * [[Atomic absorption spectroscopy]] * [[Biological control]] of [[Salvinia]] * Development of [[Linola]] (a [[flax]] variety with low [[alpha-linolenic acid]] content) with a longer life used as a stockfeed * [[Distance measuring equipment]] (DME) used for aviation navigation * [[Gene|Gene shears]] * Interscan [[Microwave landing system]], a microwave approach and landing system for aircraft * Use of [[myxomatosis]] and [[calicivirus]] to control rabbit numbers * [[Parkes Observatory|Parkes Radio Telescope]] * The permanent [[pleat]] for fabrics * [[Polymer banknote]] * [[Relenza]] flu drug * [[ISASMELT#History of the ISASMELT Process|Sirosmelt lance]] * "Softly" woollens detergent * [[Phase-contrast X-ray imaging]] * Essential components of [[Wi-Fi]] technology * Method to use titanium in [[3D printing]]{{cite news|last1=Swan|first1=David|title=Titomic soars on ASX debut, plans facility with large-scale 3D printer|url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/technology/titomic-soars-on-listing/news-story/e4462ec453a0c8c20421660ef9a245ef|work=The Australian|date=September 21, 2017}} * Ultrabattery [[UltraBattery]]{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=August 2018}} ===Historic research=== CSIRO had a pioneering role in the scientific discovery of the universe through radio "eyes". A team led by [[Paul Wild (Australian scientist)|Paul Wild]] built and operated (from 1948) the world’s first solar radiospectrograph, and from 1967 the {{convert|3|km|mi|adj=mid|-diameter}} radioheliograph at Culgoora in New South Wales. For three decades, the Division of Radiophysics had a world-leading role in solar research, attracting prominent solar physicists from around the world.{{cite web |url=http://www.csiro.au/news/ps47j |title=Dr John Paul Wild |publisher=CSIRO |date=16 May 2008 |accessdate=2012-05-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150125053338/http://www.csiro.au/news/ps47j |archivedate=25 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }} CSIRO owned the first computer in Australia, [[CSIRAC]], built as part of a project began in the Sydney Radiophysics Laboratory in 1947. The CSIR Mk 1 ran its first program in 1949, the fifth electronic computer in the world. It was over 1,000 times faster than the mechanical calculators available at the time. It was decommissioned in 1955 and recommissioned in Melbourne as CSIRAC in 1956 as a general purpose computing machine used by over 700 projects until 1964.{{cite web |url=http://www.csse.unimelb.edu.au/dept/about/csirac/ |title=CSIRAC |publisher=[[University of Melbourne]] |work=Department of Computer Science and Engineering |accessdate=2006-05-08 |author1=Steven Pass |author2=David Hornsby |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227165717/http://www.csse.unimelb.edu.au/dept/about/csirac/ |archivedate=27 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }} The CSIRAC is the only surviving first-generation computer in the world.{{cite web |url=http://www.museum.vic.gov.au/csirac/ |title=Museum Victoria's CSIRAC information site|accessdate=2008-04-26 }} Between 1965 and 1985, [[George Bornemissza]] of CSIRO's Division of Entomology founded and led the [[Australian Dung Beetle Project]]. Bornemissza, upon settling in Australia from Hungary in 1951, noticed that the pastureland was covered in dry cattle dung pads which did not seem to be recycled into the soil and caused areas of rank pasture which were unpalatable to the cattle. He proposed that the reason for this was that native Australian dung beetles, which had co-evolved alongside the marsupials (which produce dung very different in its composition from cattle), were not adapted to utilise cattle dung for their nutrition and breeding since cattle had only relatively recently been introduced to the continent in the 1880s. The Australian Dung Beetle Project sought, therefore, to introduce species of dung beetle from South Africa and Europe (which had co-evolved alongside bovids) in order to improve the fertility and quality of cattle pastures. Twenty-three species were successfully introduced throughout the duration of the project and also had the effect of reducing the pestilent bush fly population by 90%.{{cite journal | author = Bornemissza G. F. | year = 1976 | title = The Australian dung beetle project 1965–1975 | url = | journal = Australian Meat Research Committee Review | volume = 30 | issue = | pages = 1–30 }} ===Domain name=== CSIRO was the first Australian organisation to start using the Internet{{cite web|url=http://www.aarnet.edu.au/about-us/history.aspx |title=AARNET – About Us – History |publisher=[[Australian Academic and Research Network]] |accessdate=16 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110412054848/https://www.aarnet.edu.au/about-us/history.aspx |archivedate=12 April 2011 }} and was able to register the [[second-level domain]] csiro.au (as opposed to csiro.org.au or csiro.com.au). Guidelines were introduced in 1996 to regulate the use of the [[.au]] domain. ==Governance and management== {| class="toccolours floatleft mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="font-size:90%;" |- !colspan="4" bgcolor="#00CCFF"|
