page.title: The Complex: How the Military Invades Our Everyday Lives

revision.comment: /* Reception */HTTP to HTTPS for [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]], replaced: http://www.motherjones.com/ → https://www.motherjones.com/ using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Other uses|The Complex (disambiguation){{!}}The Complex}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''The Complex: How the Military Invades Our Everyday Lives''}} {{Infobox book | name = The Complex | title_orig = | translator = | image = The Complex by Nick Turse.gif | caption = Book cover | author = Nick Turse | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[United States military]] | genre = [[Non-fiction]] | publisher = Metropolitan Books | pub_date = 2008 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Hardcover | pages = 304 | isbn = 0-8050-7896-7 | dewey= 338.4/735500973 22 | congress= HC110.D4 T873 2008 | oclc= 163708073 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Complex: How the Military Invades Our Everyday Lives''''' is a book about the United States military, written by [[journalist]] [[Nick Turse]]. It was published in 2008 in hardcover format by Metropolitan Books. The book describes the vast changes in the industrial complex of the U.S. military from the days of [[President of the United States|President]] [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] to 2008, its effect on American society, and how the military and private business spheres interact with each other. The book received positive reviews in [[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] and ''[[Inter Press Service]]'', and critical reviews by Jeffrey St. Clair of ''CounterPunch'', and in ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]''.
==Background== Nick Turse received a [[Ph.D.]] from [[Columbia University]] in Sociomedical Sciences.<ref name="nelson">{{cite book | last =Nelson | first =Deborah | title =The War Behind Me: Vietnam Veterans Confront the Truth about U.S. War Crimes | publisher =Basic Books | date =November 3, 2008 | pages =192 | isbn = 0-465-00527-6}}</ref> His Ph.D. dissertation is titled: " '''Kill Anything That Moves': United States War Crimes and Atrocites in Vietnam, 1965–1973'' ",<ref>[[Nick Turse]], [http://academiccommons.columbia.edu/item/ac:121522 Kill Anything That Moves : U.s. War Crimes And Atrocities In Vietnam, 1965–1973], a doctoral dissertation, Columbia University 2005</ref><ref>[[Nick Turse]], [http://www.japanfocus.org/-Nick-Turse/2956 “A My Lai a Month: How the US Fought the Vietnam War”], The Asia-Pacific Journal, Vol. 47-6-08, November 21, 2008</ref> and it utilized the war-crime archive and historical texts to analyze the doctrine of atrocity.<ref name="nelson" /> Turse is the research director of TomDispatch.com, a project of ''The Nation Institute''.<ref name="nelson" /> He is the recipient of a James Aronson Award for Social Justice Journalism, and in 2009 received a Ridenhour Prize for Reportorial Distinction.<ref>{{cite news|last=Turse|first=Nick| title =Hunkering Down For The Duration? | work = [[CBS News]] | publisher = [[CBS]] | date =November 10, 2009 | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/11/10/opinion/main5600852.shtml | accessdate = 2009-12-19}}</ref> ''The Complex'' is Turse's first book.<ref>{{cite news| last = Engelhardt | first =Tom |authorlink=Tom Engelhardt |author2=Nick Turse | title =The Pentagon's Stealth Corporations | work = LewRockwell.com | language = | publisher =www.lewrockwell.com | year = 2008 | url = http://archive.lewrockwell.com/engelhardt/engelhardt342.html | accessdate =February 23, 2016 }}</ref>
==Synopsis== Nick Turse explores how the industrial complex of the United States military has pervaded the everyday lives of Americans. Turse investigates the relationship between the Pentagon and the Hollywood entertainment industry, military actions in the civilian sphere, and joint projects between the U.S. military and companies including [[NASCAR]] and [[Marvel Comics]]. Turse describes how military tacticians and flyers were outfitted with [[Apple, Inc.|Apple]] [[PowerBook]]s. He illustrates how the military has attempted innovative methods to reach out to and recruit contemporary youth, including making "friends" on [[MySpace]]. Turse notes that the research and development budget of the military, and its spending in the private sector, has increased dramatically over the last few years. The book posits that many changes have occurred since [[President of the United States|President]] [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]]'s military-industrial complex, and relates the changes to the present day.
==Reception== The book was reviewed in ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'', where it was recommended: "For those who like their journalism fevered and their politics pat."<ref name="kirkus">{{cite journal | last =Kirkus Reviews staff | title =The Complex – Or, buy an iPod, kill an Iraqi | journal =[[Kirkus Reviews]] | publisher =Nielsen Business Media, Inc. | date =January 15, 2008 }}</ref> [[Tom Engelhardt]] of ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'' magazine wrote, "It's an eye-opener on the degree to which we are, without realizing it, a militarized society."<ref>{{cite news | last =Engelhardt | first =Tom |authorlink=Tom Engelhardt | title =The Golden Age of the Military-Entertainment Complex | work =[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] | date =March 20, 2008 | url =https://www.motherjones.com/commentary/tomdispatch/2008/03/golden-age-of-the-military-entertainment-complex.html | accessdate = 2008-11-21 }}</ref> Engelhardt called ''The Complex'' a "superb book".<ref>{{cite news| last = Engelhardt | first =Tom|authorlink=Tom Engelhardt | title = Hungry and Without Options in New York| work =[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]] | date =April 26, 2009 | url = http://motherjones.com/politics/2009/04/hungry-and-without-options-new-york | accessdate = 2009-12-19 }}</ref> Jeffrey St. Clair of ''CounterPunch'' was critical, and commented: "This is a Bush-bashing book that maliciously elides the uncomfortable fact that many of the contractor scandals that penetrated the mainstream press in Bush-time where ''[sic]'' actually set in motion in the 1990s."<ref>{{cite news | last =St. Clair | first =Jeffrey | title =Booked Up | work =CounterPunch | publisher =www.counterpunch.org | date =April 26, 2008 | url =http://www.counterpunch.org/stclair04262008.html | accessdate = 2008-11-21}}</ref> Chris Barsanti of ''[[PopMatters]]'' gave the book a rating of 3 out of a possible 10, and wrote, "''The Complex'' is an airless and rather pointless recitation of facts that feels cut-and-pasted rather than written."<ref>{{cite news| last =Barsanti | first =Chris | title = The Complex: How the Military Invades Our Everyday Lives | work = [[PopMatters]] | publisher = PopMatters Media, Inc. | year = 2009 | url = http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/the-complex-by-nick-turse/ | accessdate = 2009-12-19}}</ref>
Ali Gharib reviewed the book for ''[[Inter Press Service]]'', and noted: "Turse's book carefully tracks the Defense Department's money trail to everything from traditional defense contractors to a handful of Southern catfish restaurants to Dunkin' Donuts."<ref>{{cite news | last =Gharib | first =Ali | title =Book Shows Pentagon's Ties to Hollywood, Dunkin' Donuts | work =[[Inter Press Service]] | date =June 26, 2008 }}</ref> Victoria Segal of ''[[The Guardian]]'' reviewed the book and commented, "Much of Turse's research holds the Pentagon up to ridicule: their golf courses, the fast-food-addicted army that waddles rather than marches on its stomach. Yet the book turns sinister when it exposes desperate recruiters who allow white supremacists to join up, or defence department plans to develop 'weaponised' moths and sharks. References to The Matrix could make Turse seem a paranoid geek. Unfortunately, this is no sci-fi fantasy."<ref>{{cite news| last =Segal | first = Victoria | title = Saturday Review: Paperbacks: Non-fiction: The Complex , by Nick Turse | work =[[The Guardian]] | publisher =Guardian Newspapers Ltd | date =June 27, 2009 }}</ref> David Swanson of ''[[Political Affairs Magazine]]'' wrote, "Nick Turse has done something pretty amazing in producing an entertaining account of the almost limitless variety of ways in which our money is wasted by what he calls the military industrial technological entertainment academic media corporate matrix, or 'The Complex' for short".<ref>{{cite news| last = Swanson | first = David | title = Where Your Tax Dollar Will and Will Not Go | work = [[Political Affairs Magazine]] | language = | publisher = www.politicalaffairs.net | date =April 12, 2008 }}</ref>
==See also==
*[[Investigative journalism]] *[[Military-industrial complex]] *[[Vietnam War Crimes Working Group Files]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

The '''TopGun Designation''' in the [[capital market]]s is awarded by Brendan Wood International. The designation is based upon over 10,000 debriefings globally with [[portfolio manager]]s, [[CEO]]s, [[CFO]]s, other senior [[corporate executive]]s, leading broker analysts and [[merchant|trader]]s. Corporates executives assess their TopGun Investment Bankers. TopGun Portfolio managers are awarded based upon the evaluations provided by leading broker analysts. Influential [[investor]]s nominate TopGun CEOs, CFOs, Companies, and the Boards who earn their highest investor confidence votes. Investors also evaluate their top broker analyst and institutional sales professionals. TopGun traders are awarded based on the input from [[buy side]] traders. Recipients often include the TopGun designation in their resumes and on their [[website]]s.{{Original research inline|date=January 2011}} The designation has been featured on many leading news outlets. The designation is awarded annually or every two years depending on the discipline and capital markets activity. The first ever TopGun Ball was held in [[Toronto]] for charity, “A Fusion of Performance and Philanthropy”, and will be{{when|date=January 2011}} mirrored in [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]], [[New York City]], [[London]] and [[Hong Kong]]. ==References==
https://archive.is/20130123212734/http://www.forbes.com/2009/06/22/top-gun-ceos-intelligent-investing-survey_slide.html
https://web.archive.org/web/20100119084916/http://kinross.com/about-kinross/our-history/2009.aspx
http://www.canadianbusiness.com/markets/marketwire/article.jsp?content=20090902_181511_12_ccn_ccn{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}
http://blogs.reuters.com/great-debate/tag/topgun-ceo/ ==External links== * [http://www.brendanwood.com] The designation is awarded by Brendan Wood International [[Category:Investment management]] [[Category:Business and industry awards]]

{{About|the business meaning|computer gaming groups|Virtual airline (hobby)}} In [[economics]], a '''virtual airline''' is an [[airline]] that has [[outsource]]d as many possible operational and business functions as it can, but still maintains effective control of its core business.<ref> {{cite book |title=Designing and Executing Strategy in Aviation Management |last=Flouris |first=Triant |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CJXshJc_IpIC |year=2006 |publisher=Ashgate Publishing |isbn=0-7546-3618-6 |pages=91 }} </ref> Such an airline focuses on operating a network of air services, and outsourcing non-core activities to other organizations.<ref> {{cite book |title=The Airline Business |last=Doganis |first=Rigas |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UnVAfY8J6OcC |year=2005 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=0-415-34615-0 |pages=283 }} </ref> Contracting out services within the aviation industry has reportedly become so common that many carriers could be classed as having features of a virtual airline, although it is arguable whether any current carriers meet a strict definition of the term.<ref> {{cite book |title=The Economic Geography of the Tourist Industry: A Supply-side Analysis |last=Ioannides |first=Dimitri |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P4PfF5LAijYC |year=1998 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=0-415-16411-7 |pages=118 }} </ref><ref>{{cite book |title=The Contracting Organization: A Strategic Guide to Outsourcing |last=Domberger |first=Simon |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XkqHg1N7w6YC |year=1998 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=0-19-877458-3 |quote=British Airways [has] lean[ed] towards becoming the first of the new general of '''Virtual Airlines''' |pages=146 }}</ref>
The term is also used to describe travel companies and ticket agencies that market themselves as airlines, but are unlicensed and with flights undertaken by licensed operators often in the livery of the virtual airline.
==Origins==
Virtual airlines originated following the drastic changes brought about by the [[Airline Deregulation Act of 1978]]. During the hyper-competitive years immediately following deregulation, [[mainline (flight)|major airlines]] found it increasingly unprofitable to compete against start-up carriers on many routes they currently served. Instead of forfeiting the routes entirely, the larger carriers often made marketing arrangements with smaller airlines to fly under the "banner", or [[aircraft livery]], of the larger airline. These [[regional airline]]s, mimicking the well known major airlines in adverts and prescribing to make connections as seamless as possible, soon abandoned their own local service routes. In most cases, the regional airlines found it more profitable to serve the mainline hubs as a feeder operation rather than operate on their own.{{citation needed|date=July 2014}}
[[File:Manx2plane.jpg|right|thumb|A Dornier 228 with the livery of virtual airline [[Manx2]], the aircraft was actually operated by FLM aviation with Manx2 being a ticket broker.]]

===North America===

(airline)|Go!]] (defunct) * [[Go!Express]] (defunct) * [[JetSuiteX]] * [[NewLeaf]] (defunct) * [[Ravn Alaska]] * [[Hageland Aviation|Ravn Connect]] (defunct) * [[Southern Skyways]] * [[United Express]]
